messageBody:
Robert,

This is an interesting idea. It would be very powerful. I'm having trouble
understanding what you would use it for beyond what you can do with
@Before/@After and @BeforeClass and @AfterClass, though. Do you have an
example?

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Robert Watkins
> Sent: Tuesday, June 14, 2005 5:00 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
> > @Test takes two optional parameters. A test annotated
> @Test(timeout=100)
> > will fail if the test takes longer than 100 milliseconds to
> complete. A test
> > annotated @Test(expected=NullPointerException.class) will fail if a
> > NullPointerException is not thrown and succeed if a
> NullPointerException is
> > thrown.
>
> Kent,
>
> These are both examples of decorators (as I'm sure you know).
>
> Rather than simply hard-code in just two decorators, is there
> any chance
> you could provide a generic parameter for defining decorators
> on a per test
> method (and class) basis?
>
> e.g.
> @TestSuite(decorator=foo.bar.WibbleDecorator.class)
> public class SomeTest {
>
> @Test(decorator=foo.bar.XyzzyDecorator.class)
> public void testWhatever() {
> ...
> }
> }
>
>
> The decorator support in JUnit is a very powerful technique,
> and one that's
> been underutilised by many JUnit extensions. One reason is
> that decorating
> tests isn't that easy - while suite-level decorators aren't hard,
> testcase-level decorators require populating the suite by hand. :(
> Annotation-based decorator declaration would go a long way to
> solving that.
>
> I'd also like to see an annotation-based version of the
> suite() method,
> thus keeping in the trend of providing alternatives to the existing
> reflection based techniques.
>
> Robert.
